sen.j: 平城京（へいぜいきょう、へいじょうきょう）は、かつての日本の首都。
sen.e: Heizei-kyo or Heijo-kyo used to be the ancient capital of Japan.
Heijo-kyo (also pronounced Heizei-kyo) used to be the ancient capital of Japan.
Heijo-kyo (also pronounced Heizei-kyo) used to be the ancient capital of Japan.

sen.j: いわゆる「奈良の都」である。
sen.e: It is also known as 'the capital of Nara.'
It is also known as 'the capital of Nara.'
It is also known as 'the capital of Nara.'

sen.j: 唐の都「長安」や北魏洛陽などを模倣して建造されたとされ、現在の奈良県奈良市および大和郡山市近辺に位置していた。
sen.e: The capital which was located in current Nara City, Nara Prefecture and the vicinity of Yamatokoriyama City is thought to be modeled after 'Changan' of Tang Dynasty and Rakuyo in Northern Wei Dynasty.

The capital, which was located in current Nara City, Nara Prefecture, and the vicinity of Yamatokoriyama City, is thought to be modeled on 'Changan' of the Tang Dynasty and Rakuyo of the Northern Wei Dynasty.

The capital, which was located in current Nara City, Nara Prefecture, and the vicinity of Yamatokoriyama City, is thought to be modeled on 'Changan' of the Tang Dynasty and Rakuyo of the Northern Wei Dynasty.

sen.j: 歴史
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: 藤原京から平城京への遷都は707年（慶雲4）に審議が始まり、708年（和銅元）には元明天皇により遷都の詔（都というものは「百官の府であり、四海の人々が集まるところ」）が出された。
sen.e: The discussion on the transfer of the capital from Fujiwara-kyo to Heijo-kyo began in 707, and an edict of the transfer (which stated that the capital was 'the center of government offices and the place where people gathered across the ocean') was issued by Empress Genmei in 708.

The discussion on the transfer of the capital from Fujiwara-kyo to Heijo-kyo began in 707, and in 708 Empress Genmei issued an edict of the transfer, which stated that the capital was 'the center of government offices and the place where people of the world gather'.
sen.cmt: Wording, more natural translation of 四海
sen.e: The discussion on the transfer of the capital from Fujiwara-kyo to Heijo-kyo began in 707, and in 708 Empress Genmei issued an edict of the transfer, which stated that the capital was 'the center of government offices and the place where people of the world gather.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: 平城の地は、三方が山に囲まれ南が開け、占いにもかなっている。
sen.e: Three sides of the Heijo property were surrounded by mountains and one open side was facing south, which were considered to be positive in feng shui way
sen.cmt: ここでの占いは風水と訳しました。
sen.e: Three sides of the Heijo property were surrounded by mountains and one open side was facing south, which was considered to be positive according to feng shui.
Three sides of the Heijo property were surrounded by mountains and one open side was facing south, which was considered to be positive according to feng shui.

sen.j: しかし、710年（和銅3）に遷都された時には、内裏と大極殿、その他の官舎が整備された程度と考えられており、寺院や邸宅は、山城国の長岡京に遷都するまで、段階的に造営されていったと思われる。
sen.e: However, when it was relocated in 710, it is believed that the construction of only a few facilities such as the Imperial Palace, Daigokuden and official residences were completed, and other facilities like temple and residence were being constructed step by step till the capital was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in Yamashiro Province.

However, when it was relocated in 710, it is believed that the construction of only a few facilities such as the Imperial Palace, Daigokuden (the central building) and official residences were completed, and other facilities like the temple and residence were being constructed step by step until the capital was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in Yamashiro Province.
sen.cmt: I took this explanation of Daigokuden from row 55.
sen.e: However, when it was relocated in 710, it is believed that the construction of only a few facilities such as the Imperial Palace, Daigokuden (the central building) and official residences were completed, and other facilities like the temple and residence were being constructed step by step until the capital was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in Yamashiro Province.

sen.j: 740年、恭仁京への遷都によって平城京は一時的に放棄されるが、745年には、再び平城京に遷都され、その後784年（延暦3年）、長岡京に遷都されるまで74年間都がおかれ政治の中心地であった。
sen.e: Although Heijo-kyo was temporally abandoned due to the transfer of the capital to Kuni-kyo in 740, it was relocated to Heijo-kyo once again in 745 and became the center of the government for 74 years till it was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in 784.

Although Heijo-kyo was temporarily abandoned due to the transfer of the capital to Kuni-kyo in 740, it was relocated to Heijo-kyo once again in 745 and was the center of the government for 74 years, until it was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in 784.

Although Heijo-kyo was temporarily abandoned due to the transfer of the capital to Kuni-kyo in 740, it was relocated to Heijo-kyo once again in 745 and was the center of the government for 74 years, until it was transferred to Nagaoka-kyo in 784.

sen.j: 山城国に遷都したのちは南都（なんと）とも呼ばれた。
sen.e: After it was relocated to Yamashiro Province, it was also called as Nanto.
After it was relocated to Yamashiro Province, it was also called 'Nanto'.
After it was relocated to Yamashiro Province, it was also called 'Nanto.'
sen.cmt: ピリオド位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: 810年9月6日、平城天皇によって平安京を廃し平城京へ遷都する詔が出された。
sen.e: On September 6, 810, an edict of destroying Heian-kyo and transferring the capital to Heijo-kyo was issued by Emperor Heisei.
On September 6, 810, an edict to destroy Heian-kyo and transfer the capital to Heijo-kyo was issued by Emperor Heisei.
On September 6, 810, an edict to destroy Heian-kyo and transfer the capital to Heijo-kyo was issued by Emperor Heizei.

sen.j: これに対し嵯峨天皇が迅速に兵を動かし、9月12日、平城上皇は剃髪した（薬子の変）。
sen.e: Emperor Saga raised an army due to the opposition and the retired Emperor Heizei became a Buddhist monk on September 12 (known as the Kusuko Incident).
Emperor Saga opposed this and swiftly raised an army, and the retired Emperor Heizei became a Buddhist monk on September 12 (known as the Kusuko Incident).
sen.cmt: Clarify what Saga is in opposition to
sen.e: Emperor Saga opposed this and swiftly raised an army, and the retired Emperor Heizei became a Buddhist monk on September 12 (known as the Kusuko Incident).

sen.j: これによって平城京への遷都は実現することはなかった。
sen.e: Because of this incidence, the transfer of the capital to Heijo-kyo did not happen.
Because of this incident, the transfer of the capital to Heijo-kyo did not happen.
Because of this incident, the transfer of the capital to Heijo-kyo did not happen.

sen.j: 名称
sen.e: Name
Name
Name

sen.j: 以前は学校教科書において「へいじょうきょう」と振り仮名がふられていたが、現在は多くの教科書で「へいぜいきょう」とふられている。
sen.e: It was previously spelled as 'Heijo-kyo' in the school textbooks, however, it is now mostly spelled as 'Heizei-kyo.'
It was previously spelled as 'Heijo-kyo' in the school textbooks, however, it is now mostly spelled as 'Heizei-kyo.'
It was previously spelled as 'Heijo-kyo' in the school textbooks, however, it is now mostly spelled as 'Heizei-kyo.'

sen.j: 平城天皇が「へいぜい」と読むことや、「へいじょう」は漢音＋呉音の表記であることなどから、漢音表記に統一した「へいぜい」とされた。
sen.e: It is because the name Emperor Heizei is read as 'heizei,' and the pronunciation of 'heijo' was a combination of the Han and Wu reading of Chinese characters, and therefore, was changed to 'heizei' by simply using the Han reading.

The Emperor's name '平城' is read as 'Heizei,' and the pronunciation of 'Heijo' was a combination of the Han and Wu reading of the same Chinese characters, so the standard writing was changed to 'Heizei' by simply using the Han reading.
sen.cmt: This makes little sense without use of the kanji. Changed to capital letters for Heizei/Heijo.
sen.e: The Emperor's name '平城' is read as 'Heizei,' and the pronunciation of 'Heijo' was a combination of the Han and Wu reading of the same Chinese characters, so the standard writing was changed to 'Heizei' by simply using the Han reading.

sen.j: しかし世論的には未だ「へいじょう」が一般的であり、奈良県の進める平城遷都1300年記念事業も「へいじょう」と発音されている。
sen.e: However, the name 'heijo' is still commonly used, and Commemorative Events of the 1300th Anniversary of Nara Heijo-kyo Capital organized by Nara Prefecture also uses the term 'heijo.'
However, the name 'Heijo' is still commonly used, and Commemorative Events of the 1300th Anniversary of Nara Heijo-kyo Capital organized by Nara Prefecture also uses the term 'Heijo.'
However, the name 'Heijo' is still commonly used, and Commemorative Events of the 1300th Anniversary of Nara Heijo-kyo Capital organized by Nara Prefecture also uses the term 'Heijo.'

sen.j: このように、平城京は現代においては音読みで「へいじょうきょう」または「へいぜいきょう」と読むが、かつては「ならのみやこ」と訓読みしたというのが定説である。
sen.e: As it is stated above, Heijo-kyo is now read as 'heijokyo' or 'heizei-kyo,' however, it is believed that it was once read as 'Nara no Miyako.'
As stated above, Heijo-kyo is now read as 'Heijokyo' or 'Heizei-kyo,' however, it is believed that it was once read as 'Nara no Miyako.'
As stated above, Heijo-kyo is now read as 'Heijo-kyo' or 'Heizei-kyo,' however, it is believed that it was once read as 'Nara no Miyako.'
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。

sen.j: なぜ「平城」を「なら」と読むのかは諸説あるが、一番有力とされているのは「平坦な都」という意味である。
sen.e: Although there are many different theories of why '平城' was pronounced as 'nara,' a well accepted theory states that it came from the meaning 'flat city.'
Although there are many various theories as to why '平城' was pronounced as 'Nara', one well accepted theory states that it came from the meaning 'flat city.'
Although there are many various theories as to why '平城' was pronounced as 'Nara,' one well accepted theory states that it came from the meaning 'flat city.'
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: 現代においても起伏のある土地を平坦にすることを「土地をならす」というが、「なら」には平坦という意味があり、山がちな飛鳥から平坦な奈良盆地の真ん中に移った都という意味が込められているとされるのがこの説である。
sen.e: Since the word 'nara' is used to describe flattening an undulating land even in modern day, one theory states that the name came from the relocation of the capital from a mountainous place Asuka to the middle of Nara Basin.

Since the word 'nara' is used to describe flattening an undulating land even in modern day, one theory states that the name came from the relocation of the capital from the mountainous place Asuka to the middle of the Nara Basin.

Since the word 'nara' is used to describe flattening an undulating land even in modern day, one theory states that the name came from the relocation of the capital from the mountainous place Asuka to the middle of the Nara Basin.

sen.j: そのため「平」の字を使ったが、中国風に雅字（良い文字の意）二字で地名を表記するために、「城市」の意を込めた「城」の字との2文字で「平城」とし、都の名称として採用したのではないかとされている。
sen.e: Therefore, the letter '平' was chosen, and in order to make it into a Chinese style, '城' having the meaning of '城市 (fortified town)' was added, and they were together used for the name of the capital '平城.'

Because of this the character '平' was chosen, and in order to use the Chinese style, which uses two character for place names, '城' from the word '城市' (fortified town) was added, and they were together used for the name of the capital '平城.'
sen.cmt: Translation lacked information regarding use of 2 characters for place names.
sen.e: Because of this the character '平' was chosen, and in order to use the Chinese style, which uses two character for place names, '城' from the word '城市' (fortified town) was added, and they were together used for the name of the capital '平城.'

sen.j: ちなみに「奈良」や「寧楽」などは「なら」という発音の万葉仮名表記である。
sen.e: Incidentally, the pronunciation 'なら (nara)' is written as '奈良' or '寧楽' based on Mayodan (early Japanese syllabary composed of Chinese characters used phonetically).
Incidentally, the pronunciation 'なら (Nara)' is written as '奈良' or '寧楽' based on Manyo-gana (an early Japanese syllabary composed of Chinese characters used phonetically).
sen.cmt: Is this translation of 万葉仮名 as Mayodan ok? Different from terms in column C and could not find it, so changed to Manyo-gana.
sen.e: Incidentally, the pronunciation 'Nara' is written as '奈良' or '寧楽' based on Manyo-gana (an early Japanese syllabary composed of Chinese characters used phonetically).
sen.cmt: 「」を' 'に訂正しました。「なら（）」削除しました。

sen.j: かつては朝鮮語の「ナラ（国という意味）」との関連性を指摘する学者もいたが、現在はほぼ否定されている（「均す（なら-）『平らにする』」という意味が語源とされている）。
sen.e: There used to be scholars who suggested the possible connection with the word 'nara (meaning a country)' in Korean, however, this theory is no longer accepted (the origin of the word is believed to be 'to flatten').

There used to be scholars who suggested a possible connection with the Korean word 'nara' (meaning a country), however, this theory is no longer accepted (the origin of the word is believed to be 'to flatten').

There used to be scholars who suggested a possible connection with the Korean word 'nara' (meaning a country), however, this theory is no longer accepted (the origin of the word is believed to be 'to flatten').
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 都市計画
sen.e: City Planning
City Planning
City Planning

sen.j: 都市計画の概要
sen.e: Summary of City Planning
Summary of City Planning
Summary of City Planning

sen.j: 平城京は南北に長い長方形で、中央の朱雀大路を軸として右京と左京に分かれ、さらに左京の傾斜地に外京（げきょう）が設けられている。
sen.e: The shape of Heijo-kyo was a long rectangle which had Suzaku-oji Street dividing Ukyo (west part of capital) and Sakyo (east part of the capital), and further down the Sakyo, Gekyo (extra part in the east part of Heijo-kyo) was constructed on sloping ground.

The shape of Heijo-kyo was a long rectangle which had Suzaku-oji Street dividing Ukyo (west part of capital) and Sakyo (east part of the capital), and further down the Sakyo, Gekyo (extra part in the east part of Heijo-kyo) was constructed on sloping ground.

The shape of Heijo-kyo was a long rectangle which had Suzaku-oji Street dividing Ukyo (west part of capital) and Sakyo (east part of the capital), and further down the Sakyo, Gekyo (extra part in the east part of Heijo-kyo) was constructed on sloping ground.

sen.j: 東西軸には一条から九条大路、南北軸には朱雀大路と左京一坊から四坊、右京一坊から四坊の大通りが設置された条坊制の都市計画である。
sen.e: The city planning was based on jobo system (a series of avenues running at right angles to each other marked out the system) and was constructed from Ichijo to Kujo-oji Street running through east to west, Suzaku-oji Street and from Ichibo to Shibo Streets in Sakyo running through north to south, and from Ichibo to Shibo Street in Ukyo.

The city planning was based on the jobo system (a series of avenues running at right angles to each other marked out the system) and was constructed with Ichijo to Kujo-oji Street running through east to west, from Suzaku-oji Street and Ichibo to Shibo Streets in Sakyo running through north to south, and from Ichibo to Shibo Street in Ukyo.

The city planning was based on the jobo system (a series of avenues running at right angles to each other marked out the system) and was constructed with Ichijo to Kujo-oji Street running through east to west, from Suzaku-oji Street and Ichibo to Shibo Streets in Sakyo running through north to south, and from Ichibo to Shibo Street in Ukyo.

sen.j: 各大通りの間隔は約532m、大通りで囲まれた部分（坊）は、堀と築地（ついじ）によって区画され、さらにその中を、東西・南北に3つの道で区切って町とした。
sen.e: Each major street was separated by an area of roughly 532m, and those surrounded areas (known as Bo) were divided by mud walls and ditches, which were then divided with three streets running down from north to south and east to west and called towns.

Each major street was separated by an area of roughly 532m, and those surrounded areas (known as Bo) were divided by mud walls and ditches, which were then divided into towns by three streets running down from north to south and east to west.

Each major street was separated by an area of roughly 532m, and those surrounded areas (known as Bo) were divided by mud walls and ditches, which were then divided into towns by three streets running down from north to south and east to west.

sen.j: 京域は北辺坊を除いて東西約6.3km、南北約4.7kmに及ぶ。
sen.e: It measured 4.3 km from east to west and 4.8 km from north to south excluding the northern bo.
The capital measured 4.3 km from east to west and 4.8 km from north to south excluding the northern bo.
sen.cmt: Clarified that 'it' refers to the capital.
sen.e: The capital measured 4.3 km from east to west and 4.8 km from north to south excluding the northern bo.

sen.j: 市街地の宅地は、位階によって大きさが決められ、高級貴族が占める4町のものを筆頭として、2町・1町・1/2町・1/4町・1/8町・1/16町・1/32町などの宅地が与えられた。
sen.e: The properties of urban areas were divided based on ones' ranks which allowed the high rank nobles to have 4 towns, and the rest were followed by 2, 1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16, 1/32 town.
The residential land of urban areas was divided based on one's rank, which allowed the high rank nobles to have 4 towns, and the rest were followed by 2, 1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16, 1/32 town.
The residential land of urban areas was divided based on one's rank, which allowed the high rank nobles to have 4 towns, and the rest were followed by 2, 1, 1/2, 1/4, 1/8, 1/16, 1/32 town.

sen.j: 土地は公有制であるため、原則的には天皇から与えられたものであった。
sen.e: Since each land was publicly owned, it was generally given by the emperor
Since land was publicly owned, it was generally given by the emperor.
Since land was publicly owned, it was generally given by the emperor.

sen.j: 以前は唐の都の長安を模倣して作られたというのが一般的な定説であったが、先行する藤原京との密接な関係から現在は関連が疑われており、北魏洛陽などをモデルとした、日本独自の発展系ではないかという見方も有力となっている。
sen.e: Although it was a well established theory that the capital was modeled after the Changan of Tang Dynasty, its close relationship with Fujiwara-kyo, which had previously been built, became questionable, and therefore another theory became accepted, which stated that Rakuyo in Northern Wei Dynasty was the inspiration, yet the development of the capital was unique to Japan.

Although it was a well established theory that the capital was modeled after Changan of Tang Dynasty, its relationship with Fujiwara-kyo, previously thought to be close, became questionable, and therefore another theory became accepted, which stated that Rakuyo in Northern Wei Dynasty was the inspiration, yet the development of the capital was unique to Japan.

Although it was a well established theory that the capital was modeled after Changan of Tang Dynasty, its relationship with Fujiwara-kyo, previously thought to be close, became questionable, and therefore another theory became accepted, which stated that Rakuyo in Northern Wei Dynasty was the inspiration, yet the development of the capital was unique to Japan.

sen.j: つまり、中国の辺境の異民族の侵略を重く見た軍事的色彩の濃い城壁でなく、きわめて政治的な都市であった。
sen.e: In other words, it was an political city rather than a military city which had a concern over the invasion by different ethnic groups in remote regions of China
In other words, it was a political city, rather than a military city concerned with invasion by different ethnic groups from remote regions of China.
In other words, it was a political city, rather than a military city concerned with invasion by different ethnic groups from remote regions of China.

sen.j: 平城京の市街区域は、大和盆地中央部を南北に縦断する大和の古道大和の古道下ッ道・大和の古道中ッ道を基準としている。
sen.e: The urban area of Heijo-kyo was constructed based on Shimotsu-michi Street and Nakatsu-michi Street of the ancient paths in Yamato Province which divided the middle part of the Yamato basin into north and south.

The urban area of Heijo-kyo was constructed based on Shimotsu-michi Street and Nakatsu-michi Street of Yamato no kodo (the ancient paths in Yamato Province), which divided the middle part of the Yamato basin into north and south.

The urban area of Heijo-kyo was constructed based on Shimotsu-michi Street and Nakatsu-michi Street of Yamato no kodo (the ancient paths in Yamato Province), which divided the middle part of the Yamato basin into north and south.

sen.j: 下ツ道が朱雀大路に当たり、中ツ道が左京の東を限る東四坊大路（ただし少しずれる）に当たる。
sen.e: Shimotsu-michi Street hit Suzaku-oji Street, and Nakatsu-michi Street hit East Shibo-oji Street which divided the eastern part of Sakyo (although slightly off).
Shimotsu-michi Street met Suzaku-oji Street, and Nakatsu-michi Street met East Shibo-oji Street, which divided the eastern part of Sakyo (although slightly off).
Shimotsu-michi Street met Suzaku-oji Street, and Nakatsu-michi Street met East Shibo-oji Street, which divided the eastern part of Sakyo (although slightly off).

sen.j: 二条大路から五条大路にかけては、三坊分の条坊区画が東四坊大路より東に張り出しており、これを外京と呼ぶ。
sen.e: The extra section projecting from Nijo-oji Street and Gojo-oji Street was called Gekyo which was the size of three bo.
The extra section projecting from Nijo-oji Street and Gojo-oji Street was called Gekyo, and was the size of three bo.
The extra section projecting from Nijo-oji Street and Gojo-oji Street was called Gekyo, and was the size of three bo.

sen.j: また、右京の北辺は二町分が北に張り出しており、これを北辺坊と称する。
sen.e: There were also two blocks projecting toward north from the northern part of Ukyo and was called Hokuhenbo.
There were also two blocks projecting north from the northern part of Ukyo, and this area was called Hokuhenbo.

sen.j: 平城京の建築物
sen.e: Architectures Inside Heijo-kyo
Architectures Inside Heijo-kyo
Architectures Inside Heijo-kyo

sen.j: 平城宮（大内裏）は朱雀大路の北端に位置し、そこに朱雀門が設置された。
sen.e: Heijo-kyu Palace was located on the north end of Suzaku-oji Street, and Suzaku-mon Gate was constructed there.
Heijo-kyu Palace was located at the north end of Suzaku-oji Street, and Suzaku-mon Gate was constructed there.
Heijo-kyu Palace was located at the north end of Suzaku-oji Street, and Suzaku-mon Gate was constructed there.

sen.j: 平城宮は平城京造営当初から同じ位置に存在した。
sen.e: Heijo-kyu Palace was always in the same location ever since Heijo-kyo was being constructed.
Heijo-kyu Palace has always remained in the same location ever since the construction of Heijo-kyo.
Heijo-kyu Palace has always remained in the same location ever since the construction of Heijo-kyo.

sen.j: その中心建物である大極殿は740年の遷都の際に取り壊され、後に旧位置の東側に再建された。
sen.e: The central building known as Daigokuden was once destroyed when relocating the capital in 740 yet later reconstructed on the east side of the original location.
The central building known as Daigokuden was demolished when relocating the capital in 740, and later reconstructed on the east side of the original location.
The central building known as Daigokuden was demolished when relocating the capital in 740, and later reconstructed on the east side of the original location.

sen.j: 朱雀大路の南端には羅城門があり、九条大路の南辺には京を取り囲む羅城があった。
sen.e: There was Rajo-mon Gate on the south end of Suzaku-oji Street as well as Rajo, which was built to surround the capital, on the southern area of Kujo-oji Street.
Rajo-mon Gate was on the south end of Suzaku-oji Street, and Rajo, which was built to surround the capital, was on the southern area of Kujo-oji Street.

sen.j: ただし、実際には羅城は羅城門に接続するごく一部しか築かれなかったのではないかとする説が有力である。
sen.e: However, it is likely that only a part of Rajo conjoining to Rajo-mon Gate was actually constructed.
However, it is likely that only a small part of Rajo attached to Rajo-mon Gate was actually constructed.
However, it is likely that only a small part of Rajo attached to Rajo-mon Gate was actually constructed.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 寺院建築は非常に多い。
sen.e: There were many temple architectures.
Many temples were constructed.
Many temples were constructed.

sen.j: 京内寺院の主要なものは、大安寺、薬師寺、興福寺、元興寺（以上を四大寺と称した）で、これらは藤原京から遷都に際して順次移転されたものである。
sen.e: The major temples constructed in the capital were Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple and Gango-ji Temple (together called the four great temples), and each were relocated one by one when the capital was transferred from Fujiwara-kyo.

The major temples constructed in the capital were Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple and Gango-ji Temple (together called the four great temples), and each were relocated one by one when the capital was transferred from Fujiwara-kyo.

The major temples constructed in the capital were Daian-ji Temple, Yakushi-ji Temple, Kofuku-ji Temple and Gango-ji Temple (together called the four great temples), and each were relocated one by one when the capital was transferred from Fujiwara-kyo.

sen.j: 東大寺は東京極大路に接した京域の東外にあり、聖武天皇によって752年に創建、西大寺 (奈良市)は右京の北方に位置し、称徳天皇により天平神護元年（765年）に創建された。
sen.e: Todai-ji Temple was constructed on the east side of East Kyogoku-oji Street by the order of Emperor Shomu in 752 while Saidai-ji Temple (located in Nara City) was constructed on the north side of Ukyo by the order of Emperor Shotoku in 765.

Todai-ji Temple was constructed on the east side of East Kyogoku-oji Street by the order of Emperor Shomu in 752, while Saidai-ji Temple (located in Nara City) was constructed on the north side of Ukyo by the order of Emperor Shotoku in 765.

Todai-ji Temple was constructed on the east side of East Kyogoku-oji Street by the order of Emperor Shomu in 752, while Saidai-ji Temple (located in Nara City) was constructed on the north side of Ukyo by the order of Emperor Shotoku in 765.

sen.j: これらに法隆寺を加えて七大寺（南都七大寺）と称する。
sen.e: Horyu-ji Temple and 6 others mentioned above are together called the seven great temples (Seven Great Temples of Nara)
Horyu-ji Temple and the 6 others mentioned above are together called the seven great temples (Seven Great Temples of Nara).
Horyu-ji Temple and the 6 others mentioned above are together called the seven great temples (Seven Great Temples of Nara).

sen.j: 2006年3月10日、大和郡山市教育委員会らが、平城京が十条大路まで作られていたのは確実であると発表した。
sen.e: On March 10, 2006, it was announced by the Yamatokoriyama board of education that it was certain there was Jujo-oji Street constructed in Heijo-kyo.
On March 10, 2006, it was announced by the Yamatokoriyama board of education that Jujo-oji Street was certainly constructed in Heijo-kyo.
On March 10, 2006, it was announced by the Yamatokoriyama board of education that Jujo-oji Street was certainly constructed in Heijo-kyo.

sen.j: 道路の遺構に加え、羅城（城壁）跡の一部が発見されたことによる。
sen.e: It was due to the excavation of the street as well as a part of Rajo (walls).
This was due to discovery of remains of the street, as well as part of Rajo (walls).
sen.cmt: Translation a little inaccurate - made more literal.
sen.e: This was due to discovery of remains of the street, as well as part of Rajo (walls).

sen.j: この羅城は中国の都城のような土壁ではなく、簡単な瓦葺きの板塀ではないかとみられている。
sen.e: This Rajo is thought to be built with simple tiled roof and wooden walls unlike the one in China, which was built with mud walls.
This Rajo is thought to have been built with a simple tiled roof and wooden walls, unlike the one in China, which was built with mud walls.
This Rajo is thought to have been built with a simple tiled roof and wooden walls, unlike the one in China, which was built with mud walls.

sen.j: 何面だけは高い築地塀があった。
sen.e: There were a few high walls present.
There were a few high walls present.
There were a few high walls present.
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 発掘・調査
sen.e: Excavation and Research
Excavation and Research
Excavation and Research

sen.j: 北浦定政が、自力で平城京の推定地を調査し、水田の畦や道路に街の痕跡が残ることを見つけ、1852年（嘉永5）『平城宮大内裏跡坪割之図』にまとめた。
sen.e: When investigating the possible location of Heijo-kyo, Sadamasa KITAURA discovered that the ruins of the city could remain on the ridges between rice fields and streets, which he recorded in "Heijo-kyu Daidairi ato tsubowari no zu," 1852.

When investigating the possible location of Heijo-kyo, Sadamasa KITAURA discovered that ruins of the city remained on the ridges between rice fields and streets, which he recorded in "Heijo-kyu Daidairi ato tsubowari no zu," in 1852.

When investigating the possible location of Heijo-kyo, Sadamasa KITAURA discovered that ruins of the city remained on the ridges between rice fields and streets, which he recorded in "Heijo-kyu Daidairi ato tsubowari no zu," in 1852.

sen.j: さらに関野貞は、大極殿の基壇を見つけ、平城宮の復元研究を深めて、その成果を『平城宮及大内裏考』として1907年（明治40）に発表した。
sen.e: In addition, after Tadashi SEKINO discovered the stylobate of Daigokuden and conducted research on the restoration of Heijo-kyu Palace, its results were published as "Heijo-kyu oyobi Daidairi ko" in 1907.

In addition, after Tadashi SEKINO discovered the stylobate of Daigokuden and conducted research on the restoration of Heijo-kyu Palace, its results were published as "Heijo-kyu oyobi Daidairi ko" in 1907.

In addition, after Tadashi SEKINO discovered the substructure of Daigokuden and conducted research on the restoration of Heijo-kyu Palace, its results were published as "Heijo-kyu oyobi Daidairi ko" in 1907.

sen.j: 棚田嘉十朗によって「奈良大極殿保存会」が設立され、1924年から平城宮の発掘調査が行われた。
sen.e: Nara Daigokuden Preservation Society' was established by Kajuro TANADA, and the excavation of Heijo-kyu Palace was begun in 1924.
Nara Daigokuden Preservation Society' was established by Kajuro TANADA, and the excavation of Heijo-kyu Palace began in 1924.
Nara Daigokuden Preservation Society' was established by Kajuro TANADA, and the excavation of Heijo-kyu Palace began in 1924.

sen.j: 1959年以降は、奈良国立文化財研究所が発掘を継続しており、2004年現在では、約30%が発掘されている。
sen.e: Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties is continuing the excavation since 1959, and about 30% of the capital was uncovered by 2004.
Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties has been continuing the excavation since 1959, and about 30% of the capital was uncovered by 2004.
Nara National Research Institute for Cultural Properties has been continuing the excavation since 1959, and about 30% of the capital was uncovered by 2004.

sen.j: 大内裏に相当する辺りは現在の近畿日本鉄道近鉄奈良線大和西大寺駅と新大宮駅の中間にあり、1922年には史跡に指定、1952年には特別史跡（平城宮跡（へいじょうきゅうせき））として保存されている。
sen.e: The current location of Daidairi is roughly midway between Yamato-Saidaiji Station and Shin-Omiya Station of Kintetsu Nara Line owned by Kinki Nippon Railway Company, and was nominated as a historic site in 1922 and later as a special historic site in 1952.

The current location of Daidairi is roughly midway between Yamato-Saidaiji Station and Shin-Omiya Station on the Kintetsu Nara Line owned by Kinki Nippon Railway Company, and was nominated as a historic site in 1922 and later as a special historic site in 1952.

The current location of Daidairi is roughly midway between Yamato-Saidaiji Station and Shin-Omiya Station on the Kintetsu Nara Line owned by Kinki Nippon Railway Company, and was nominated as a historic site in 1922 and later as a special historic site in 1952.

sen.j: また朱雀大路の一部（二条〜三条あたり）が1984年に史跡に指定されている。
sen.e: A part of Suzaku-oji Street (Nijo - Sanjo) was also nominated as a historic site in 1984.
A part of Suzaku-oji Street (the area from Nijo to Sanjo) was also nominated as a historic site in 1984.
A part of Suzaku-oji Street (the area from Nijo to Sanjo) was also nominated as a historic site in 1984.

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Others
Others
Others

sen.j: 遷都の年号の語呂合わせは「710（南都）きれいな平城京」、もしくは「710（南都）大きな平城京」、「710（南都）素敵な平城京」、「710（南都）美しい平城京」など。
sen.e: There are some puns to describe the year of the transfer of the capital such as 'how (710 can be pronounced as nanto meaning how and Nanto in Japanese) beautiful Heijo-kyo is,' 'how big Heijo-kyo is,' 'how nice Heijo-kyo is' and 'how lovely Heijo-kyo is.'

As 710 can be pronounced as 'nanto', meaning both 'how' and 'Nanto' in Japanese, there are some puns to describe the year of the transfer of the capital, such as 'how beautiful Heijo-kyo is,' 'how big Heijo-kyo is,' 'how nice Heijo-kyo is' and 'how lovely Heijo-kyo is.'

As 710 can be pronounced as 'nanto,' meaning both 'how' and 'Nanto' in Japanese, there are some puns to describe the year of the transfer of the capital, such as 'how beautiful Heijo-kyo is,' 'how big Heijo-kyo is,' 'how nice Heijo-kyo is' and 'how lovely Heijo-kyo is.'
sen.cmt: コンマの位置を訂正しました。

sen.j: 平城京はシルクロードの終着点であったことも関係し、非常に国際都市であった。
sen.e: Since it was the final destination of the Silk Road, the capital became quite an international place.
Since it was the final destination of the Silk Road, the capital became a very international place.
sen.cmt: quite' does not convey the extent of '非常に' in this instance.
sen.e: Since it was the final destination of the Silk Road, the capital became a very international place.

sen.j: それ故に京内には日本人だけではなく唐や新羅などから遠くはインド周辺の人々までみられたという。
sen.e: Therefore, there were not only Japanese but also people from Tang Dynasty, Silla and the vicinity of India inside the Heijokyo.
Therefore, there were not only Japanese but also people from Tang Dynasty, Silla and the vicinity of India inside the Heijokyo.
Therefore, there were not only Japanese but also people from Tang Dynasty, Silla and the vicinity of India inside the Heijo-kyo.
sen.cmt: ハイフン補足しました。

sen.j: 桓武天皇が、平城京から長岡京へ遷都を決めた理由の一つに、平城京の地理的条件と用水インフラへ不便さにあった。
sen.e: Two main reasons Emperor Kanmu decided to transfer the capital from Heijo-kyo to Nagaoka-kyo were the geographical location of Heijo-kyo and an inconvenient water infrastructure.
Two main reasons Emperor Kanmu decided to transfer the capital from Heijo-kyo to Nagaoka-kyo were the geographical location of Heijo-kyo and its inconvenient water infrastructure.
Two main reasons Emperor Kanmu decided to transfer the capital from Heijo-kyo to Nagaoka-kyo were the geographical location of Heijo-kyo and its inconvenient water infrastructure.

sen.j: 平城京は大きな川から離れている為、大量輸送できる大きな船が使えず、食料など効率的に運ぶことが困難であった。
sen.e: Since Heijo-kyo was built far from a big river, it was difficult to transport food efficiently without the use of ship.
Since Heijo-kyo was built far from a big river it was not possible to use a ship, so it was difficult to transport food efficiently.
Since Heijo-kyo was built far from a big river it was not possible to use a ship, so it was difficult to transport food efficiently.

sen.j: 都には小さな川は流れているが、人口10万人を抱えていた当時、常に水が不足していた。
sen.e: Although there were a few streams running down the city, it was not enough to support a population of 100,000.
Although there were a few streams running down the city, it was not enough to support a population of 100,000.
Although there were a few streams running down the city, it was not enough to support a population of 100,000.

sen.j: 生活排水や排泄物は、道路の脇に作られた溝に捨てられ、川からの水で流される仕組みになっていた。
sen.e: Domestic wastewater and excrement were thrown away into the ditches next the streets which were then flashed down with water from the streams.
Domestic wastewater and excrement were thrown away into the ditches next to the streets, and carried away by the stream water.
Domestic wastewater and excrement were thrown away into the ditches next to the streets, and carried away by the stream water.

sen.j: しかし、水がほとんど流れない為に汚物が溜まり、衛生状態は限界に達していた。
sen.e: However, as too much waste was piled up for water to flash, it became very unsanitary.
However, waste piled up causing the water to almost stop flowing, and it became very unsanitary.
However, waste piled up causing the water to almost stop flowing, and it became very unsanitary.
